Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Transition, Turbulence and Mixing in Shock-Accelerated Variable Density Flows at Extreme Conditions

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1254760
Ranjan

Many studies of mixing focus on the role played by instabilities and turbulence in an incompressible medium. However, compressibility and shocks play a critical role in many practical applications. Some examples are understanding the behavior of plumes in volcanic eruptions, design of more efficient fuel pellets for inertial confinement fusion, fragmentation of gallstones or kidney stones by shock waves, and development of energy-efficient scramjet engines. Understanding the mixing process in such complex flows presents a set of truly fundamental and open problems of in fluid mechanics that still remain to be solved. This CAREER project advances our knowledge precisely in this context, which can then be applied to these practical applications. The scientific goal of the CAREER project is to produce, diagnose, and simulate shock-driven turbulent flows in a compressible system. The system decouples hydrodynamic instabilities from the effects of radiation and plasma. The approach is to use a newly built variable-inclination shock tube with 11.5cm Ã— 11.5cm square inner cross-section, equipped with the state-of-the-art laser diagnostics (3D Particle Image Velocimetry, Planar Laser-Induced Fluorescence, as well as Rayleigh-Scattering), to answer critical scientific questions associated with shock-driven variable-density flows in configurations and regimes which have not yet been explored.

Intellectual Merit: This research will quantify the effects of initial conditions (single and multimode), incident shock wave Mach numbers (M), and density contrast on the perturbation growth and mixing rate, as well as to determine the existence of self-similar scaling laws and the critical value of Reynolds number and length scales necessary for transition to occur in these extreme mixing environments. Experiments conducted as part of this project will provide the first detailed turbulence statistics measurements (i.e., Reynolds stresses, density-velocity correlations and their spectra) for shock-accelerated variable density flows at M > 2.0 and will inform physics-based models used in simulations by testing them under more realistic conditions. This research will help develop the capability to accurately predict and model extreme mixing, potentially leading to advances in a number of fields: energy, environment (atmospheric and oceanographic), aerospace engineering, chemical processing, homeland security and, most pertinently, inertial confinement fusion (ICF) devices.

Broader Impacts: The integrated Education Plan will engage first-generation college students in experimental design and operation, support a woman graduate student to work on the proposed research, and use visualization and team-based approaches to improve students' understanding of concepts and promote communication and teamwork skills that are vital to success. The involvement of first generation students in research will lead to enhanced retention and success rates for these students in the department. An applet-based visual learning environment will enhance learning and retention of the material presented in class by allowing students to observe the dynamic phenomena and explore the effects of varying a parameter on the resulting solution. To increase awareness among the general public about shock-driven flows and their potential applications, we plan to work with a local high school teacher to create informational videos about our research and experimental facilities, post them on YouTube, and make them available to teachers for use in the classroom.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many studies of mixing focus on the role played by instabilities and turbulence in an incompressible medium. However, compressibility and shocks play a critical role in many practical applications. Some examples are understanding the behavior of plumes in volcanic eruptions, design of more efficient fuel pellets for inertial confinement fusion, fragmentation of gallstones or kidney stones by shock waves, and development of energy-efficient scramjet engines. The overarching objectives of this project were to understand the broader class of shock and buoyancy driven flows, and its ability to mix materials, often (but not always) by turbulence at extreme parameter regimes (of Reynolds, Mach, and Atwood numbers); enhance the undergraduate and graduate learning experience by implementing innovative visualization based teaching tools, and promote ?first generation college? students in engineering and science.

As part of this project, our group is first to perform simultaneous density and velocity field measurements at extreme environments with shock strengths that are greater than Mach 1.5. Our development and deployment of Particle Image Velocimetry at 200 kHz was a world record in 2018 for velocity measurements, combined density and velocity field measurements at 60KHz is still a record to beat in shock-driven flows. Through these experiments, we has established a new criterion for flow transition to turbulence at higher Reynolds number in shock-driven variable density flow of about 40,000, compared to a range of 10,000 to 20,000 that is widely accepted in literature. Such a finding, based on time-dependent nature of the flows induced by hydrodynamic instabilities, is critical for Inertial Confinement Fusion target designs.

As part of this project four graduate students (3 PhD, 1 Masters) had an opportunity to contribute and successfully defend their thesis. Three out of those four students were first-generation in college and this project really helped them with their career goals. My first doctoral student (Prof. Jacob McFarland, a first-generation college student, Associate Professor at Texas A&M University from Fall 2020 and Assistant Professor at the University of Missouri, Columbia till Fall 2020) is a recipient of ONR Early Career Award in 2020 and is an NSF CAREER Award recipient in 2019. David Reilly, Master's student, is now working at Shell. Mohammad Mohaghar (PhD 2019) is now a Postdoctoral researcher at Georgia Tech.

Through this project, we initiated several initiatives on campus to enhance support for first-generation students. At Texas A&M in 2013, I started a first-generation society in partnership with the department undergraduate coordination. Since my move to Georgia Tech, I have worked closed with several first-generation students on campus. Three undergraduates worked in my group as part of the REU supported program. Two of them are now graduate students at Penn State and Johns Hopkins University. Mr. Juan Lopez was a recipient of GEM Fellowship and was supported by Los Alamos National Lab, a partnership developed by STAM Lab. In 2019, we initiated a new fellowship program for first-generation college students by obtaining financial support from Shell Corporation, and three PhD students have been awarded this fellowship. This is particularly impressive in the sense that the students come from families with parents having no college education, and that the students have continued to progress into graduate studies beyond their four-year undergraduate program.

The most important outcome of the project has been the support and promotion of first-generation students associated with this project.

    Mohammad Mohaghar and JFM
    Devesh Ranjan
    Simultaneous Density and Velocity Field

However, compressibility and shocks play a critical role in many practical applications. As part of this project, our group is first to perform simultaneous density and velocity field measurements at extreme environments with shock strengths that are greater than Mach 1.5. Our development and deployment of Particle Image Velocimetry at 200 kHz was a world record in 2018 for velocity measurements, combined density and velocity field measurements at 60KHz is still a record to beat in shock-driven flows. Through these experiments, we has established a new criterion for flow transition to turbulence at higher Reynolds number in shock-driven variable density flow of about 40,000, compared to a range of 10,000 to 20,000 that is widely accepted in literature.
